conclusion: Analyze the motion of the dipole under the influence of the magnetic field.
Magnetic force on a charged particle moving in a magnetic field is given by F = q v x B.
Force on positive charge +q is F+ = q (v+ x B).
Force on negative charge -q is F- = -q (v- x B).
Dipole is rotating with angular velocity ω0 about its center of mass at the origin.
Velocity of positive charge is v+ = ω0 (d/2) j.
Velocity of negative charge is v- = -ω0 (d/2) j.
Magnetic field B is along the z-axis, so B = B k.
Force on positive charge is F+ = q ω0 (d/2) B (-i) = -q ω0 (d/2) B i.
Force on negative charge is F- = q ω0 (d/2) B i.
Net torque τ about the center of mass is the sum of the torques due to these forces.
Torque due to F+ is τ+ = (d/2 i) x (-q ω0 (d/2) B i) = 0.
Torque due to F- is τ- = (-d/2 i) x (q ω0 (d/2) B i) = 0.
Effective torque is τ = q ω0 (d^2/2) B k.
Moment of inertia I of the dipole about its center of mass is I = 2 m (d/2)^2 = (1/2) m d^2.
Equation of motion for angular velocity is I dω/dt = τ, simplifying to m dω/dt = q B ω0.
Differential equation dω/dt = (q B/m) ω0 integrates to ω(t) = ω0 cos(q B t/m).
Condition for dipole to reverse its orientation is ω(t) must change sign.
ω(t) = -ω0 when cos(q B t/m) = -1, giving t = π m/(q B).
Minimum ω0 required is ω0 = q B/m.
